text: When I feel the urge to eat, I pause and notice whether it's physical hunger or emotional hunger.
During stressful moments, I notice the pull to eat and choose to address the emotion directly instead.
When I feel sad or anxious, I recognize the emotion and choose healthy ways to cope instead of turning to food.
I let emotional hunger or stress drive me to eat even when I'm not physically hungry.
When I notice myself eating out of boredom, I recognize the pattern and choose a different activity instead.
I see when my mind is using food to comfort or distract me, and I choose to face the feeling directly instead.
When I feel a craving, I pause and check if my body actually needs food or if it's an emotional response.
I let food availability or convenience control my eating choices instead of listening to my body's needs.
When I notice the urge to eat for comfort, I recognize it and choose to sit with the emotion instead.
I recognize when my eating is driven by emotions rather than physical need, and I choose to address the root cause.
When I feel the pull to eat after a difficult moment, I notice it and choose to process the feeling first.
I let stress or difficult emotions automatically trigger eating without checking if I'm actually hungry.
When I notice myself eating mindlessly, I pause and bring my attention back to the present moment.
I see when my eating patterns are connected to my emotional state, and I choose to address both separately.
When I feel the urge to eat when food is just available, I check in with my body's actual hunger signals first.
I let emotional eating patterns control my relationship with food and my ability to manage feelings.
When I notice difficulty distinguishing between hunger types, I pause and use my body's signals to guide me.
I recognize when eating is a response to emotional discomfort, and I choose to feel the emotion instead.
When I feel the pull to use food as a reward or comfort, I notice it and choose healthier ways to meet that need.
I let emotional eating habits prevent me from developing healthier ways to cope with stress or difficult feelings.
